Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The evolution of symbiotic polydnaviruses in Parapanteles parasitoid wasps
Award.AbstractNarration:
When two different species have a long-term and consistent interaction they reciprocally influence each other's evolutionary fate. Understanding how these interactions with other species have shaped an organism over time is key to understanding how and why that organism is the way it is today, which is fundamentally important to understanding the complexity and diversity of nature and very useful when trying to control an organism with an economic consequence. Many types of wasps inject their eggs into the body of another living insect, which hatch into larvae that consume the host. Wasps in the subfamily Microgastrinae (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) use a specialized virus, polydnavirus, to prevent their hosts, caterpillars, from destroying their eggs and larvae. Microgastrine wasps are one of the most important ecological and agricultural natural enemies to the caterpillars of butterflies and moths, including many agricultural pests. This research will compare the genomes polydnaviruses from a small group of closely related microgastrines. This group of microgastrines was at one point a single species that attacked 1-3 species of host caterpillars, but evolved over time into about 20 species that each attack different caterpillar species. The goal of this project is to identify which virus genes changed the most and which changed the least as this group of wasps evolved into several different species which have adapted to different hosts. This will identify which virus genes have universally important functions for disabling caterpillars' immune defenses and which genes may have specific functions that are adapted to work in a specific host. This will contribute to understanding how polydnaviruses help microgastrines adapt to new host caterpillars, how they are able to adapt to thousands of different caterpillar immune systems, and why there are so many species of microgastrines. This is especially important for understanding why some groups of organisms evolve into many more species than other groups of organisms, and for discovering new ways to control caterpillar species, many of which are important agricultural pests.

Polydnavirus genes that interfere with host immunity are hypothesized to evolve rapidly in an evolutionary arms-race with the host immune adaptations. Polydnavirus genomes are integrated into the microgastrine wasps' nuclear genome. Parapanteles Ashmead is a small microgastrine genus with well-studied microgastrine host use patterns. A draft genome of Parapanteles continua has already been sequenced and assembled and putative polydnavirus genes have been identified within it. This research will sequence and assemble the genomes of 20 more Parapanteles species, annotate their polydnavirus genes, and phylogenetically investigate how these genes have evolved, especially in relation to host-switches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many types of small wasps lay their eggs inside of other insects. Larvae hatch out of those eggs and live parasitically inside their host until they are ready to pupate and kill their host. Living inside of another organism means that these larvae have to evade the host’s immune system. Microgastrinae is one such group of wasps that exclusively parasitize moth or butterfly caterpillars. They have a special adaptation to overcome the immune systems of those caterpillars: they have coopted an insect virus that suppresses insect immune systems into their genome and can then produce their own virus particles. When a female microgastrine wasp stings a host caterpillar she injects venom, eggs, and these viruses, known as Polydnaviruses, which protect the larvae from the caterpillar’s immune system.

Microgastrinae wasps are highly host-specific: one species of wasp typically only attacks one or two species of caterpillar. This aspect of their life history has been pivotal for biological control: if a species of caterpillar becomes a pest, then researchers can try producing and releasing a species of microgastrines to control that caterpillar with virtually no risk of the wasps attacking non-target species. The reason for this host specificity is still not well understood, but may have something to do with their polydnaviruses. If polydnaviruses evolve rapidly in an arms-race with a host caterpillar’s immune system, then they may not be effective enough to keep wasp larvae alive in other species of caterpillars, thus restricting a wasp to the caterpillar that its polydnavirus is adapted to. However, polydnaviruses have only been studied in a handful of microgastrine species that represent a fraction of the diversity of this group of wasps. They have also not been looked at in a group of closely-related wasps. This project more than doubled the amount of species from which the DNA of polydnvaviruses have been sequenced. The microgastrine genomes that we sequenced are all closely related, so we have been able to address how polydnaviruses evolve in similar wasps that have recently split off on different evolutionary paths. This means we were able to investigate how these viruses evolve in different evolutionary lineages and what happens when one species begins parasitizing a different host caterpillar.

To date, our results are largely qualitative but it is clear that polydnavirus genes evolve rapidly: they are frequently duplicated and also frequently broken by mutations. We were expecting to find versions of each polydnavirus gene that were slightly different because they were altered by each species’ independent evolutionary history. What we found instead was that each species had different numbers of each polydnavirus gene which were themselves drastically different from each other.  Polydnavirus researchers have hypothesized previously that polydnaviruses must evolve rapidly to “keep up” with the evolution of caterpillar immune systems, but this hypothesis had not adequately been tested. Our results corroborate this hypothesis and show what the pattern of rapid evolution looks like across many more species than have ever been compared at once.

In addition to our polydnavirus-related findings, this study created important datasets for future studies and supported and trained a graduate student’s dissertation research. This study increased the number of microgastrine genomes from 1 to 17, which will be used to study the evolution of other aspects of these wasps’ biology, such as the genes they use to detect chemicals in their environments to the genes they use to detoxify toxins in their diets. It also allowed the graduate student whose dissertation it supported to learn valuable skills in next-generation DNA sequencing techniques and genome assembly: techniques that are still relatively new and will be applied to many different types of projects in the future.
